37596589.review:
Take your average sliding tile puzzle game, you know, the ones where you have to move a piece through a labyrinth of sorts to get to the exit. Okay, now make it so that there are certain spots on the board you have to tag before reaching said exit. Now throw this into a blender with Friday the 13th. No really, you literally slide Jason (or whatever killer you want, there's loads of different ones here based on monsters from other movies, most with their own kill moves) around each level, find all the counselors, and kill them, which opens the exit. That is what Slayaway Camp is and yes, it's as amazing as it sounds.

Think the game would get too repetitive? That's when they decide to add a new game mechanic with each "film" you go through. Counselor exits in one, cops in another. [spoiler]Later on crazier stuff shows up like death lasers, SWAT units, and pitfalls galore.[/spoiler] Just when you get comfortable with the game, they add another mechanic to keep things fresh. Apparently these devs were also involved with PopCap's awesome Peggle series, which explains the simple yet addicting progression of the whole thing.

In my experience, it never got too frustrating to the point I wanted it to end either; the balance is just right for the 9 hours or so it took me to reach the end of the final movie. Since the last time I've played it, there have also been quite a few updates, adding new killers and levels, so there's plenty to love here.

[b]Recommendation:[/b] If you like puzzle games quite a bit, particularly stuff like Peggle and some of PopCap's older stuff where genuinely interesting gameplay was placed over artificial difficulty, then Slayaway Camp is practically calling for you to give it a shot. If you like Friday the 13th or just need some stress relief by taking it out on some silly cartoonish counselors, buy this game. If both statements apply, buy this game [b]now[/b]; you won't regret it.

35686944.review:
One of the best puzzle games on Steam and an awesome tribute to all things Horror for fans of the genre.

Featuring references to just about every horror film ever, the game is an addictive mix of sliding along a playing field to kill innocent campers, avoid cops, and sidestep traps, fires, and lakes.

What other game on Steam allows you to not only play as a killer snowman but also Jimsaw and the awesome Mary from American Mary?  Collecting your psuedo-Pokedex of various killers is almost more fun than the actual gameplay as you see what characters the creators are paying tribute to and including.  Add to this the developers' continued support for the game including the Monthly Murderer newsletter that includes a new playable killer kode every month and you have one amazing tribute to the genre and all things goofy, offbeat, or outright wrong that fans should love.

35686459.review:
It has long been popular in the gaming world, and even more so with the rise of indie prominence, to take simple and well established puzzle games and craft them in to something different.  Some games try to approach the core mechanics in unique ways while others simply try to create a more aesthetic change.  In the case of Slayaway Camp, the latter seems to be the route taken - but not without some interesting design shakeups along the way.  

[h1] Slide to left… slide to the right… reverse reverse![/h1]

Slayaway Camp, in a nutshell, is a basic puzzle game that has you sliding your character around to reach a goal.  Each move in a direction takes you as far as possible until encountering an obstacle.  We’ve all seen barebones games like this where your goal is to get to a certain place on a map without going off an open edge in a maze-like structure and usually in a certain number of moves.  Slayaway Camp, however, has multiple goals for you to reach and doesn’t always use a move limit.  The part that makes this game unique is that those ‘goals’ are frightened campers, and your character just happens to be a generic 80s slasher movie monster.  The visual design here is one that can be moderately entertaining if you were at all a fan of these old movies.  They make a point to have some fun with it in the intros and the blocky designs of the characters along with their often-silly faces makes it a mild affair even with the gore turned up.  They take this design to the max by having you unlocking new killers, new types of kills, and having each set of levels take place within environments that loosely reflect an overall movie narrative.  This all served to keep me interested longer than I would have assumed for a puzzle game that doesn’t tread much new ground.  

The absurdity of some of your killers actions can range from bland to somewhat hilarious, but it’s very easy to see all of them in short order if you end up repeating some levels.  Then it's easier to skip these little kill cutscenes than watch them repeat.  Slayaway camp definitely has the potential to lose its luster if you’re not already a fan of puzzle games – which I have historically had mixed feelings on.   The implementation of some of the unlockable items also shows the game’s mobile roots and makes it a little less appealing once you realize that it’s the path they’ve chosen.  

[h1]How many monies is this worth?[/h1]

Getting this game as part of a Humble Bundle full of other great games certainly made owning it a much better value proposition.  The aesthetic is undeniably an amusing package to wrap a simple set of gameplay mechanics in, and improves the longevity of a game that can be bogged down by tougher puzzles.  However, it does seem to be priced a little high on Steam for a game that is nearly a year old and has a ton of DLC available.  If you can get it on a really good sale or in a bundle like I did, it’s definitely worth checking out and can be a lot of fun for fans of both puzzle games and those classic horror flicks, but this isn’t really a must-play for people who aren’t heavily in to at least one of those.

35564201.review:
Total impulse buy. The game was on sale for cheap and I didn't even finish reading the description. Probably not the best method of purchasing a game,, but I lucked out.

This is a puzzle game. Now, I normally don't play puzzle games, so I don't have the biggest library of game knowledge to compare this to, but it reminds me of a cross between Hitman Go and one of those flash games where you try to get the car out of a parking lot, or into a certain spot in a parking lot, etc.,. Each level is a static checkerboard, and pressing in any direction will send your character, the murderer, as far in that direction as he can possibly go. The result is that you have to shift your character around using the level layout in order to reach some harder to get to squares. The game teaches you the mechanics in the beginning tutorial and then gradually ramps up the difficulty as you progress, adding more enviromental factors and different types of NPCs. 

It's a very addictive game in and of itself, but there is a lot of homage to slasher films in here. Aside from the puzzle play trial and error (and don't worry - you can use in-game currency that you collect to unlock hints or answers in case you get stuck), the longevity comes from trying to collect two things: death scenes and different murderers. Fair warning, it takes quite a lot of grinding to collect enough coins to unlock all of these things, and that would be my only gripe with this game: after a few levels, you unlock a coin grinder mini-game. While this is certainly helpful compared to playing through a stage and collected coins, I do feel it doesn't give you enough coins. Each successful scene in the mini-game nets you 10 coins. All killers are 1,000 coins, and the death scenes range from a couple hundred to 2,500. The mini-game becomes difficult by the late teens, meaning even if you are able to score 20, you're only getting 200 coins. It got to the point where I played the final deleted scene of the final movie (campaign) over and over because it routinely nets you nearly 300 coins. 

Honestly, though, I think I stuck it out just to get all the steam achievements. That in and of itself is an accomplishment for the game, as I don't normally feel the need to play over and over for these.

Overall, the game is a lot of fun, and if you're a fan of these type of puzzle games, I don't think you can go wrong. At only $9, with my 30 hours put in, that's essentially 30 cents an hour. I've averaged the total length of time a mainstream action title nets me at 12 hours. At $60, that's $5/hr., so do I think you'll get your money's worth with this game? Yes, absolutely. Even if you don't feel the need to grind out unlockables, it'll still come in at a better value if you put even two hours into this game.

35460785.review:
https://youtu.be/woq1kBHs7oY

As puzzle games go, Slayaway Camp is an absolute success. You play as a whole host of slasher movie inspired killers whose goal is to slay camp counselors in a flurry of cutesy voxel art ultragore. The gameplay itself is very reminiscent of Hitman Go, where the killer must navigate the isometric levels by sliding in a series of logical moves that result in the murder of all victims, but one wrong move could lead to the killers demise or could lead to the level becoming unwinnable. If that happens, and it almost certainly will, a convenient and unlimited rewind a turn option is available, as well as the option to restart the level altogether. The game starts out easy, almost too easy, but as you progress the levels become fiendishly difficult, but always satisfying. New concepts, challenges and stipulations are added to the levels as they go, increasing their complexity and keeping the gameplay fresh. What's great though is that the developer included an option to skip levels or receive tips, which is excellent at preventing the game from becoming too frustrating when you inevitable hit a wall.

There's tons of great unlockables in the game to keep things interesting, such as new new killers and murder animations. The killers themselves are really fun by being direct homages to iconic movies and slasher tropes in general. I felt really incentivized to complete chapters because I was excited to see what movie the next chapter was gonna be a take on. And on that note, the design direction for the game is really stellar. It does such a great job at playing up the look and feel of 80's slasher movies from the character and level design to the VHS inspired chapter select menus. On top of that, the cute block shaped characters combined with the ultra gory death animations strikes a fantastic dissonance that makes this game stand out, and really highlights that the game doesn't take itself too seriously.

Finally, the pricing for the game is reasonable at just $9. If you are looking for a puzzle game with some character, Slayaway Camp might be just what you are looking for.

35221954.review:
[h1]Slayaway Camp delivers a solid horror parody in the form of a puzzle game.[/h1]

Disclaimer: I was given my copy from the developer for my Twitch stream. I was not told to review it.  I just felt like it was a great game and I want you all to know I may be a little biased with this review.

With that out of the way, Slayaway Camp offers a lot of replay value.  It has plenty of unlockables and some frustratingly challenging puzzles as well as tons of humorous content to wade through.  If a puzzle gets too tough to figure out, you often can spend your coins on walkthroughs, though I imagine you could just as easily open a browser and watch someone's playthrough of the game.  Regardless, you can skip levels if they become frustrating, but you won't get all the rewards for completing a movie if you skip scenes.  You'll earn coins every time you complete a scene, so if you have trouble with a scene, you'll easily be able to get the coins for the walkthrough by completing old scenes over again.

This game is hilarious and offers both a gore-filled experience and a less fun, less gore-filled experience.  You don't have to play it with the blood effects.  I have not tried to play it with gore disabled, though, so I cannot comment on how well it hides or censors the murders.  It's not exactly a game created for kids, mind you.  It's a game about horror movie murderers and the silly but ultimately gory movies they star in.

Overall, it's a great game.  I recommend it to anyone who likes horror movies enough to make fun of them.  If you like puzzles, you'll enjoy it even more.  Slayaway Camp gets a 4/5.  It's not a perfect gem of a game, but it's a lot of fun and very affordable.

You can play the free (not as good) version on Kongregate: http://www.kongregate.com/games/bluewizardgames/slayaway-camp

34365677.review:
It's kind of amazing how much depth can be put into a game with a cool concept and the will to do so.

The game it's a simple puzzle game with a horror "slasher flick" type of theme attached to it, the idea is that your character can move in four directions, left, right, up, down, only that your character won't stop unless there's something blocking it's path, alternatively there can be traps, cops field's of view, or simply getting stuck in between a couple of blocks are the things that can end your run.

The game also does sometimes without warning this cool "switch" of elements in the mechanics in some of the levels, (this ones presented as movies in vcr cassettes with cool covers and "previews" in the form of cutscenes always featuring different "killers" that you'll control during the remainer of the set of levels)

The idea in most cases is simply to stay alive and kill all civilians in a level, sounds a bit dark for a game with such a "cartoony" and "cute" aesthetic, but in reality the game, while keeping it's tongue'in cheek a bit with it's mixture of humor and violence can at times borderline in brutality, whenever you... "Take out" any of your... "Targets" the game has a chance of displaying a cutscene, at times one that can be reproduced by frightening people away from you leading them into traps (fires, holes in the ground, water tombs filled with cocodriles, etc...) altho in most cases it will simply reproduce a random cutscene of a massive set of dozens of them that are quite characteristic and that can be multiplied repeatedly by spending coins that you earn in-game.

At the end of each level (in a set of them) you can earn currency by completing a time event in a cutscene in which your character will be murdering an individual, then you'll earn "coins" that you can then spend either in more killers that you can select and use in the numerous of films/levels, or alternatively in more animations for the random executions that are displayed when murdering your "enemies".

The game for the most part it's quite self-explanatory, and it has an almost perfect learning curve, I would compare it to something like Hitman Go, but I feel, as much as I love that game, this game has it's own unique aspects in it's core game design that need to be shared, and for good reason, most of them, even after attempting a level multiple times, never really frustrated me as muchs as in other game's "personal" failures, could have, Hitman Go being a perfect example of this.

Instead the game offers a really cool "mechanic" to not call it "feature" that allows you to not only revert your mistakes resetting your position to the last movement you made, but also the ability to display handy tips for the shy price of just a couple of your in-game coins, if you still can't figure things out, after your second payment for tips, the solution for the level will be revealed.

Overall i'm really pleased as well as surprised by the ammount of quality, and content there is for this game, it's an actual fleshed out release, and even then, the game feels as just another small, maybe kind of try, and see how it is, during a sale, type of title, lost within the vast Steam store library of games, I feel as if it doesn't only deserves more attention, as much as it deserves much more significant exposure on the part of the "marketing deparment" in itself, altho maybe there's not much it can be done to promote core gameplay aspects of a game that appears rather "simplistic" at first and yet internally, profoundly, it helds an amazing ammount of passion, and heart.

Good ridance, good ridance indeed.

33966587.review:
This might just be one of my favorite puzzle games of recent times. Something about the 80's horror movie vibe and voxel character gore has a lot of charm to it. In a way this is like the Broforce of puzzle games, and by that I mean, being able to play all of these classic villians, monsters, and creatures from your favorite horror films and slasher flicks instead of action movies. The humor of this game is spot on with the cheesiness of 80's slashers, and almost everything is a comedic homage to them or other well known horror movies.

The core gameplay is actually very simple, being only able to move in four directions, but trying to figure out ways to kill everyone on screen in a crude and bloody fashion, it is very addicting. It can be challenging, but never becomes too frustrating. There are several different death scenes when you kill someone, each character also has there own unique one. Something about watching these box-like characters violently murdering their victims is extremely satisfying, and humorous at times. Levels are grouped together in VHS quality worlds, each spoofing a bad B-rated slasher movie and their atrocious sequels. There's lots of unlockables to purchase with coins you earn after each level, or by playing a really fun minigame. You can buy more death scenes from the shop or more killers through the mystery box. There are a lot of characters to choose from and they seem to keep adding more, I don't think I've even unlocked them all yet. You can also use your hard earned coins to get some useful tips to beat a level if you get stuck.

I also want to point out how good the music is. It fits in so well, and the main theme song is so catchy. I had to buy the deluxe edition just for the soundtrack, and more specifically just for an mp3 of the main theme song. Only con is I wish there were more levels, there are tons already, also harder puzzles once you beat the game, but I just want more to quench my bloodlust.  Maybe we will get another DLC or hopefully a level editor in the future.

If you love puzzle games and 80's gorefests, then you should get this game. You'll get sucked in with the nostolgia and how well it makes references to all the famous slasher and horror films in the most amusing and quirky ways. Plus it's just flat out fun and addicting.

32212359.review:
Slayaway Camp is a puzzle game at its core.  It is an homage to slasher flicks of the 80s and early 90s in a puzzle game setting.  You play as a series of killers in different movies tasked with killing victims.  The catch is that you have to move in a direction until you hit a wall, object, or your victim.  If you move left, your character goes until he hits something.  So kill the victims and escape through the portal.  Simple.

But then the game starts throwing new mechanics into play.  As you progress through each scene/level, you will be introduced to different things.  Scenes which require you to finish within a certain number of turns, scenes that involve holes, mines, cops, and other objects that make your objective more difficult.  

There are quite a number of levels.  I have gotten through the first 4 movies and still it seems I have much more to get through.  If you get stuck, the game offers you a hint.  For a price, you can get a hint or a step by step walkthrough of the level.  How does this work?  You gain coins after each level, which is used to unlock these kills.

I recommend this game to puzzle fans that enjoy horror flicks, or just want a different type of puzzler.

31952051.review:
The Good: Almost everything, from the way its packed with refrences and jokes without being too in your face about them, to the fact that its a slasher movie game that actually has solid gameplay, to the fact that thanks to the addition of the N17 scenes that were not in the free online version meaning that I can keep playing after I finish the main game, to the over-the-top personalities of the slashers to the utter lack of pretentions. And you can earn lots and lots of different killers. It even will show you the solution to puzzles your stuck on for in-game money. The game engages in constant affectionate slasher movie parody without going so far it looks stupid or like it has a self-loathing complex.

The Bad: The way you grind coins actually requires reflexes, the hints are not as helpful as they could be. Also, the game's target demographic is very narrow, only people who have watched slasher movies before the era of self-awareness would get all the jokes. The game could use more options, like replacing the cats with dogs or deliberately bad picture and audio for that 'old vhs' feel. Also, its a trifle too counter-intuative at times how to solve some puzzles.

Overall, I give it a 9/10. I want more, but what is there is excellent. Only the lack content and sneaking supsicion the game is just an evil plan to get people who hate puzzle games to play a puzzle game keep me from giving it a perfect score.

31882651.review:
Скоро лето…Скоро мы все выползем из наших берлог (а кто-то останется и будет от души наворачивать сотни часов в игровых мирах), и отправимся наслаждаться волшебным миром земной природы. Скоро откроют двери все лагеря страны нашей. Проснётся из берлоги их постоянный посетитель – мистер Черепомордый. Он приезжает в лагерь каждый год. Он очень любит отдыхать и отдых его крайне своеобразен. Он не хочет загорать на солнышке, купаться и кормить комаров на пикниках. Он просто хочет убивать.

Никто не уедет живым. Даже какая-нибудь визжащая девушка, вопреки всем канонам.

Спасутся только котики.

Когда-то он был нормальным, пока его лицо не изуродовали. Судя по всему, обидели его в лагере, ибо, несмотря на то, что побывает он во многих местах, больше всего его привлекают студентишки в лагере (кое-кого в хоккейной маске в этой истории не узнаёте? Даже сюжет, где за него мстит его мама есть. И последняя часть посвящена резне в космосе!).

На самом деле он всего лишь герой серии фильмов, которые уютно расположились на уютных полках в виде старых-добрых VHS-кассет. И он не одинок – у него много друзей-убийц. Каждое место действия, каждый убийца – своеобразная отсылка или просто отличная шутка. Болельщик в хоккейной маске. Акулочеловек. Жуткая девочка из колодца. Человек в маске с фамилией Майерс. Знакомые образы, не правда ли?

Локации не менее узнаваемы. Уютный лагерь с замечательными песнями у костра (куда же без него?). Пляж с милой акулой. Парк со злобным клоуном. Офис, где обязательно произойдёт какая-то разборка. Больница с опасной медсестрой. КОСМОООООООООООС!

Джон Капалк, основатель такой фабрики маленьких, да удаленьких игр как PopCap, собрал вокруг себя пару таких же талантливых как он людей, и выдал игру, которую не стыдно поставить в один ряд с Peggle, Bejeweled и Plants vs. Zombies. Милая, забавная и в то же время очень жестокая по отношению к роду людскому (запретить!). Простенькая, даже примитивная на вид, но очень сложная и выкручивающая уровень мозгодробительства до предела. Призывающая убивать людей и пропагандирующая любовь к котикам (оказывается, это слабость не только сильных и независимых!).

Механика удивительна в своей простоте и глубине. Поначалу вы просто передвигаетесь по игровому полю убивая глупых людишек. Постепенно, с каждым набором уровней, жертвы начинают умнеть. Они чувствуют, что смерть близко и забиваются в самый дальний угол, затем и вовсе учатся убегать из здания куда глаза глядят. Также к ним присоединяются полицейские, которые ловят нашего героя стоит ему только ступить на поле с мишенью, а затем ещё и подключаются спецназовцы, которые пускают огонь стоит нам встать под луч или на поле рядом с ними. И ещё тонна преград и условностей, расписывать которые займёт слишком много текста в этом обзоре. Самое главное это то, что тут есть котики. И их нельзя убивать.

И каждая условность, каждый элемент механики служит как на пользу, так и во вред. Абсолютно всё здесь либо убивает вашу жертву, либо убивает вас. Лежащая бомба может при толковом применении убить жертву. А может вас. Шкаф может стать непроходимым препятствием. А может убить последнюю жертву на уровне. Всё это, в комплекте с тонной вариаций убийств, даёт свободу мышления и творчества, благо, многие уровни предполагают несколько путей прохождения. Но почти каждое крайне неочевидное.

Если вы видите костёр, это не значит, что кто-то обязательно должен сгореть в нём (кстати, за первую сгоревшую жертву вам дадут достижение «Огонь, пойдём со мной» ^_^). Не стоит топить в озере всех подряд.  Если на уровне есть возможность выключить электричество чтобы не убиться током, то не стоит сразу бежать к переключателю. Игра постоянно заставляет нестандартно мыслить и перебирать самые неочевидные варианты, и при учёте наличия нескольких вариантов прохождения на многих уровнях это дарит игре высокую реиграбельность.

Да даже без неё контента тут хватает. Оригинальные фильмы содержат в себе более 200 уровней. После прохождения всего контента каждый фильм обзаведётся вырезанными сценами и так же сценами 18+. В магазине лежат целые комплекты великолепных способов избавиться от квадратных смертных. Трясущаяся коробка с скрытым в ней случайным убийцей так и манит к себе. И моя любимая часть игры и вишенка на торте – замечательная мини-игра под названием «Смертельные лица 3». Суть проста – просто нажимать мышкой когда черепушка появляется в красной зоне на полоске. Но боже, как же она затягивает за счёт прекрасной музыки на фоне и этих мило распадающихся на кровавые пиксели человечков!

Если за вашей играющей только в серьёзные и крупные ААА-тайтлы натурой прячется личность, которая не прочь отвлечься на маленькую, но сделанную с душой и любовью ко взятой тематике игрушку, то двери лагеря смерти открыты для вас. И не только летом, а круглый год. Благо, путёвка стоит крайне дёшево, а эмоций по ней вы получите как от хорошей ААА.

P.S. В качестве дополнения приложу лишь малый перечень того, что можно совершить в этой игре:
1. Наблюдать за квадратными девушками в душе (строго 18+! Автор обзора и разработчики не несут ответственность за полученные душевные травмы)
2. Напугать котика так, что он убьёт всех жертв за вас.
3. Стать криповым клоуном и пугать таких же детей как вы, когда впервые увидели «Оно».
4. Снять своё независимое кино про Майкла Майерса, призывающего Сатану, и Фредди Крюгера в космосе.
5. Делать из людей оригами.

P.P.S. Обязательно обзаведитесь делюкс контентом! Получите набор замечательных стишков о смерти, бумажные фигурки, экслюзивных убийц и замечательный саундтрек ;)

P.P.P.S. И новогоднее ДЛС прихватите.

P.P.P.P.S. Русская локализация – великолепна.

31762405.review:
Slayaway Camp is a simple, straightforward puzzle game where you play the killer in an 80s style slasher flick who has to navigate various traps and use the layout of the rooms you're in to efficiently murder your victims. Just like any good puzzle game, the game's mechanics start off super simple and get increasingly complex (as traps, stacking and scaring victims, and the authorities get involved) the further along you go making for some pretty serious head scratchers toward the end. 

Lots of unlockable characters and even more unlockable death sequences (little animated bits that play during/between levels). 

Enjoyed the puzzle mechanics and enjoyed the developer's genuine affection for 70s/80s slasher movies. For an under-$10 indie game, it has a ton of content (hundreds of puzzles) but if you want to just do the main "story" content, it won't take you more than 8-10 hours. 

Only knocks on the game I would say are the Minecraft-y look which was initially a turnoff for me but that's probably a selling point for some people and there seemed to be too many levels where there was essentially one solution which made it very trial and error. Still... definitely recommended for fans of smart puzzle games and double recommended if you also enjoy the campiness (no pun intended) of old 80s slasher movies.

31511710.review:
Fan of easy-to-learn yet challenging puzzle games? Sure!
Fan of gory slasher flicks from the 80's? Yeah! (But what does that have to do with anything?)
Would you like a game that mixed both? Wait..., WHAT!? :O

Slayaway Camp is a sliding puzzle game where you take control of the main hero (come on, everyone knows that the killers in those movies were the true heroes!) in each movie of the "Slayaway Camp" series. Each movie is made up by many set pieces (puzzles) where the goal is to slay all victims. It all starts simple enough, but each chapter introduces new mechanics that add quite a bit of challenges the farther you go. Fortunately the game offers the chance to skip troublesome levels, as well as offering some advice or a video showing you how to solve a particular puzzle in exchange of in-game money. (This is great, since it allows players of all skill levels to enjoy the game!)

The game's graphics are quite unique. Everything looks quite cute, until the blood starts flowing (be sure to check the game options to adjust everything to your liking as well as having a laugh!) The music definitely follows suit with moody and scary tunes, as well as a couple of 80's style hair-band rock tunes. I mean, you even get a horrid hippie-style song as the main theme in one of the game's most memorable puzzles! ;)

Controls are simple and easy to use, whether you are playing with a mouse or a gamepad. (Something to take into notice would be the fact that the mouse tends to override a gamepad's input while navegating the game's menus, but on the whole it is not a big deal)

Although the game can be played and enjoyed by pretty much anyone, the game is definitely geared to slasher flick fans who will have just as much fun locating all the references. Packed with plenty of content, the game is sure to bring you back for quite a while! :D

31232600.review:
Slayaway Camp is a puzzle game at heart themed around a collection of slasher movies. Bringing those two elements together comes off well and enhances the core gameplay. It's a brain twister, literal and figurative.

The rules are easy to learn and new mechanics are introduced throughout the game at certain points. It's a nice little detail that the developers worked out a fitting way to implement mechanics that are in line with the actual theme of the movies. It only makes sense to have a shark scaring people into drowning or to put in portal tiles in a spacey sci-fi flick. The puzzles as such have the right amount of complexity with misleading arrangements and sometimes only one right solution. Because the level areas maintain a manageable size, the puzzles are never overwhelming but tricky. 

While solving puzzles generally doesn't require external motivations, Slayaway Camp further awards the player with points to spend on a variety of unlockable death animations and random murder costumes. It's a minor treat but still I found myself in anticipation of which classic or unusual murder costume the game had in store next.

It's a puzzle game with an addictive gameplay and killer coating.

31082839.review:
I've not finished all the movies/levels yet but I'm going to write this review anyway since I have faith that the quality won't drop off far enough for me to want to retract anything I say.

Slayway Camp is your basic block sliding puzzler but with a hell of a lot of character thrown in. Instead of sliding to press switches, or change coloured blocks, you're sliding around campgrounds, beaches, hospitals and more as a masked killer on the loose looking for victims.

If you're a fan of 80's slasher flicks this game will be right up your alley, it does homage to them (especially the Friday the 13th films) very well, down to the cheesy synth-rock ballads and the killer's refusal to hurt animals. Each level pack is given a trailer with increasingly forced puns and justifications for the killer to be killing....a lot like most slasher franchises of the 80's and 90's.

With each movie (set of levels) a new mechanic is added, such as environmental hazards, the previously mentioned animals, police officers which will arrest you if you enter their range, SWAT which have level-crossing lasers and will fire at will and more. With each new system put in place the levels become more and more strategic, having you need to take absolutely all risks into account before making a move. 

Slayway Camp's star feature, in my opinion, are the levels where you're given a very tight amount of moves to kill all your victims and escape in. The game absolutely shines here, you can't mess up even once and it's incredibly satisfying once you figure out the perfect route to complete the level. 

The only negatives I can think of are that the previous mentioned new mechanics are often given very, very easy levels to figure them out in - I understand why this was put in place but it is a little annoying that 2/13 of each level set's levels will be a total cakewalk, even on the later levels. 

My only other 'criticism' of Slayway Camp is that it may be better purchased on mobile devices rather than on Steam as the UI is definitely more suited to a phone or tablet than it is for a desktop, and the design is definitely suited for 'pick up and play' style use, if that's what you're looking for in a game. 

If you want to check it out before buying it you can play a couple of the level packs on Kongregate.

31073759.review:
Slayaway Camp is a game about two things: sliding and gore. It provides a solid and well-balanced gameplay experience, but SC does have a couple annoying things that make it tedious. I also had my fill of this type of puzzle experience after several hours. Other players that stick with the game will find a good number of maps and victims to clear.

SC oozes b-movie horror vibes all over the place. It’s funny if you understand the references and tropes that the game parodies. Did I mention the blood? There’s plenty of bones and blood with all the victim slaying that one does. There are also different kinds of executions available to purchase to keep things fresh on the slaying front. You can play as different killers depending on the movie (set of levels tied by a theme) selected or any that you unlocked. Revisiting the movies to play the deleted scenes levels is recommended since more jokes are found there.

The blocky aesthetic works pretty well overall except for the close-ups when a cutscene execution is triggered. That’s when the game is at its worst graphically. The models don’t look very good at that distance, but the unique executions are fun to look at for the first few times. They do wear out their welcome after a while, but thankfully, you can skip them with the press of a button. The slow-motion executions that can trigger are a good time that result in an explosion of bits and pieces.

The gameplay is the strongest part of the whole sliding experience, partially due to the developer deftly handling the pacing of new obstacles and mechanics. The game starts off simple with your character sliding across the tiles without much to stop you. Over time, you’ll encounter pits, water, cats, mines, police officers, S.W.A.T., and more. They all contribute to a fun and challenging experience. I thought the idea with light switches was really neat because of how it changed victim/police behavior. When it comes to the tools available for figuring out the moves to make, you can easily restart the map, rewind, or fast forward your moves.

There’s also a system in place for buying hints and solutions. You can also skip levels instead if you don’t have the money (there’s an uninteresting mode you can play for gold which is comprised of quick time executions). I definitely bought a few solutions after coming to a complete standstill mentally.

So, if you like the GO series or sliding puzzles in general (not the tile ones), Slayaway Camp should provide slides for days. You’ll enjoy it much more if you’re familiar with the references, but the solid gameplay, over-the-top kills, and silliness in general put this game somewhere in between above average and good.

[h1]TYTUŁ[/h1]
SLAYAWAY CAMP
[h1]Producent i wydawca[/h1]
Blue Wizard Digital
[h1]Data wydania[/h1]
25 października 2016

[h1]PLUSY[/h1]
+Ciekawe zagadki logiczne,
+Przyjemny soundtrack,
+Przyjemna grafika,
+Mięsista rozgrywka,
+Nacisk na horrory klasy B,
+Bogaty wybór protagonistów,
+Wiele sposobów na dokonanie żywota naszych ofiar.

[h1]MINUSY[/h1]
-Niektóre zagadki mogą nas przyblokować,
-trochę uboga playlista,
-plansze mogłyby być większe.

[h1]OCENA[/h1]
8/10

[h1]Wstęp[/h1]
Głównym założeniem SLAYAWAY CAMP jest nakręcenie scen do horroru klasy B. 
Wcielamy się w mordercę i uśmiercamy w kreatywny sposób bezbronnych ludzi.

[h1]Rozgrywka[/h1]
Cały trzon rozgrywki opiera się na poruszaniu po dość małych mapach i na opracowaniu pomysłu jak dostać się do każdego bohatera danej sceny i skrócenie go o głowę. Niestety albo i stety nasz bohater jak już ruszy w danym kierunku to nie potrafi się zatrzymać. Dopiero jakaś przeszkoda lub ofiara zatrzymuje go. I tutaj tkwi cały patent na rozgrywkę, by tak wszystko zaplanować, aby zabić wszystkich i dostać się do strefy końcowej (pentragramu). Po każdym ukończonym poziomie 
czeka nas swego rodzaju finisher lub jak kto woli to brutalne wykończenie, które dostarcza monet...

[h1]Sterowanie[/h1]
Sterowanie nie jest skomplikowane, gdyż wystarczy nam WSAD lub gałka od kontrolera X360/PS3/4.

[h1]Postęp[/h1]
Za każdy ukończony poziom otrzymujemy monety, które możemy wykorzystać w sklepie na odblokowanie kolejnych zabójców, sposobów na dekapitację oponenta oraz całych "GORE PACK". Co daje nam dostęp do kolejnych odcinków. 

[h1]Grafika[/h1]
Na pierwszy rzut oka grafika nie robi dobre wrażenia, wygląda na prostą i niestaranną, ale wiedza na temat horrorów
klasy B, powoduje, że wiemy o tym iż styl graficzny pasuje idealnie do idei takich filmów. Pozwala na utrzymanie lekko kiczowatego klimatu horrorów klasy B i przedstawienie eksterminacji w ciekawy sposób, bez strasznie skomplikowanych skryptów i animacji (które czasem zawodzą :P)

[h1]Muzyka[/h1]
Ścieżka dźwiękowa jest dobra, lecz jest jej za mało i to jest jej główna wada.

[h1]Podsumowanie[/h1]
Gra jest warta uwagi. Gier tego typu nie jest zbyt wiele, więc ma szanse na wypracowanie sobie dobrej pozycji przed konkurencją. Polecam każdemu kto lubi zagadki logiczne, a przede wszystkim fanom horrorów klasy B.

I don't want to sound over-hyped, so I'll just keep it simple. This game is cool. Sticking straight to the facts, this is a puzzle game that works through the filter of an 80's B-Horror film series! Each level is a "Scene", and when you complete a whole campaign, you unlock a "Movie". The movie shows up on a traditional video store shelf, complete with original VHS box art that you can flip around andd read the back of. For all those who grew up in the 80's, or at least were old enough to esperience the "Classic" horror movies of that time, THIS, is a really good throwback omajge to that whole genra. Especially now that Wes Craven has passed away, it feels like movies are going to start sucking. But this game allows you to play as "The Killer" !!!! Not another helpless victim. It comes along with an awesome sounding metal/rock esc music track, additional unlockable killer characters, unlockable fatalities, and up to at least 12 movies/campaigns!!!! 

  The best part about this game for me was the actual gameplay. The puzzle solver in me/ocd freak, enjoys the puzzles. While the kid who was litterally raised on "DOOM" just LOVES the killer/gore humor! (Seriously. You can hype it up, or turn it down to suite your needs, or mood). They even have a "Faces of Death" movie that allows you to play a mini game to earn extra skull coins. SO if you're getting really frustrated on a particular scene, you can stop, earn some coins, then come back and either get a hint, or unlock a walkthrough of how to beat it. THIS FEATURE IN PARTICULAR, I feel really takes off the stress that can build up durring a lot of puzzle type games, typically in which you are stuck but have no way of figuring out ahow to move on.

  And now, they've added a couple of DLC's, Including "Santa's slay" Which includes unlocking, "Crampus",  "Stripe" from the Gremlins movie, "Santa Skullface" and many more. All amplified by soft comforting music straight from the nutcracker sweet, as yu kill oversexed lesbian elves at the shopping mall santa location after hours!!! I LOVE THIS GAME!!!!!!

30631028.review:
A killer puzzle game where you slide an adorable voxel murderer around hundreds of isometric puzzle levels to squash, flay, and decapitate hapless victims in this darkly comic homage to 80s horror.

Slayaway Camp is a funny, isometric, voxel puzzle game about murdering hapless teenagers / office workers / astronauts / other people / everything but cats. Your avatar, which you can choose from several iconic characters, can slide up, down, left, right, and there are more than 100 levels of sliding your hapless victims towards their death in flames, holes, electric fences and various other circumstances. The game is fun if repetitive, it's also a perfect companion to Halloween.

I liked:
* the humour
* puzzles (in short bursts)

I disliked:
* it gets repetitive after a while

Buy this if:
* you like some sokoban-y puzzles

Don't buy this if:
* you're against brutality in games
* you expect rich story

30476960.review:
[h1] Slayaway Camp – дикая головоломка об убийце и жертвах [/h1]

Эта мясовая головоломка была создана ребятами из Blue Wizards Digital: Джейсоном Капалкой, дизайнером Bejeweled, и Идом Ехиели, создателем серии игр Cardinal Quest, Нейтом Шмолдом, Джесси Росс и Тристаном Далом на движке Unity. Игра была хорошо оценена критиками, которые ставили Slayaway Camp самые лучшие оценки. Игра так же была бесплатной на kongregate.com. Позже, 25 октября 2016 года Slayaway Camp выходит в Steam. На данный момент её цена составляет 5.99$.

[list]

[*] Slayaway Camp представляет из себя некую головоломку, в которой вам предстоит играть за убийцу и ваша цель это, конечно же, жертвы. Вы убийца который жил себе спокойно, но грязные людишки создали лагерь около вашего дома и вас это взбесило. Покажите людям своё нежелание видеть их в своём поселке. 
Управление возможно осуществлять двумя способами: мышкой, свапая героя в нужную сторону или же стрелочками на клавиатуре. Управление удобное, так же его можно поменять в настройках игры. Мой вам совет, поставьте в настройках «Настройки настроек» на Максимум. Тогда у вас появится ещё больше возможностей в настройках игры.
Всего в Slayaway Camp около 12 глав, которые состоят из 10-20 уровней. Каждая глава проходится за пол часа – час. Прохождение всей игры у вас займёт около 12-13 часов, не считая бонусных глав, которые откроются вам по мере прохождения игры.
С каждой главой в игру вводятся новые правила, которые вы не должны нарушать. Например, в третьем эпизоде появятся кошки, которых нельзя убивать, поэтому нужно больше задумыватся над прохождением. Часто бывает так, что вы всех убили, но выйти не получится, ведь вам нужно продумать, кто же должен быть последней жертвой на уровне. 
Разнообразие на уровнях колоссальное. Каждый эпизод отличается своим уникальным стилем прохождения. 
Так же в игре есть система добиваний, из-за которой вы сможете наблюдать расчленение вашей жертвы на кусочки. Выглядит это достаточно комично из-за своей графической составляющей. 
В игре реализирован внутриигровой магазин, в котором вы сможете приобрести новых убийц, новые добивания и новые уровни. Всё это покупается за внутриигровую валюту, которую вы зарабатываете после добивания жертвы в конце каждого уровня. 
В игре так же есть много разных отсылок к фильмам 80-тых. Например, первый убийца за которого вы будете играть ну уж очень сильно напоминает Джейсона из «The Friday: 13». 

[*] Графически игра действительно замечательная. Каждый уровень проработан достаточно хорошо, а вот дизайнеру уровней действительно нужно выдать премию, ибо иногда над уровнями нужно очень сильно подумать. Скриншот добивания вы можете посмотреть по этой ссылке: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=882398541 .

[/list]

Вердикт:[i] Очень мясная головоломка, которая сделана в стиле лютых и кровавых 80-тых. За свою цену это самая весёлая и самая интересная головоломка. Советовать могу любителям головоломок, а ещё больше эта игра подойдёт любителям мяса.

I don’t usually review games on Steam but if you don’t get this and you are into puzzlers then you are missing one of the better offerings on here.

The mechanics of the game have been done before but the style it is presented in, which is of an 80's slasher movie makes it standout. The animations are great and every blood splattered blocky death is done with humour and great animation. The puzzles, whilst some simple , some are not so obvious and sometime you kill the last person with a smile on your face thinking you have completed the level, only to find you are now stuck and can’t reach the exit, at which point you can use the rewind feature, that takes you back through your steps one at a time, allowing you to continue from any point in the level, this is animated like an old VHS tape rewinding. The way the puzzles are constructed and the need to position some victims in the level by such mechanics as scaring them in a certain direction, or getting their attention with a ringing phone, ensure that the way the puzzles are solved is in keeping with the theme of the slasher movie genre. 

A great game, reasonably priced and fun to play. Exactly what a game should be.

29555184.review:
Fun puzzle game and great idea to mix sliding puzzles with old school horror

So obviously the game isn't a HORROR game, it wont scare you. Soundtrack is pretty good for that however, It fits well. 

This game has you play as a killer and you can only go in full directions left right up or down. 
Players have to kill all the victims and then exit via a portal, at the end of a level you get a bonus kill scene where you can earn some extra money to spend. 

Money can be spent on unique fatality kills or unlock new killers too, you can also use money to get a hint for a puzzle or even get a full sequence on how to complete the puzzle too. Mind you, all of these are expensive so you'll have to pass a lot of puzzles in order to buy them, which keeps you playing. 

As levels progress, new features are added. there will be victims you're not allowed to kill and there will be victims who can actually kill you. You also have traps, hazards and other objects which will alter the puzzle together.

Some puzzles are easy and some will get you quite frustrated. We're all different in how we think and solve puzzles in general so you'll always be challenged in some way and sometimes you'll blitz no problem.

I hope they can introduce some kind of workshop support for this game. I'm up to the NC-17 videos which provide some extremely challenging puzzles and being a colourful game too with its simple graphics, I'd say its a very enjoyable game. 

#endorse5natch

29438945.review:
This is without question an extraordinarily cute, fun puzzle game that just happens to be saturated in gore.

As a parody of 80's slasher flicks, Slayaway Camp succeeds and is also very addictive and fun. It never takes itself seriously and the result is an excellent puzzle game.

Its casual, its fun, its relaxed; the puzzles are interesting to work out and are generally in the 'sweet spot' of difficulty (i.e. they make you feel like you achieved something without being painful (and if any puzzle is painful there is a fair hint system and they'll even give you the solution if you need it)). The mood is very much a lighthearted dark-humor, and you can't help but smile when playing it.

Overall, this is a fantastic puzzle game; its funny, its cute, it delivers chuckles and intriguing puzzles. I unreservedly recommend it.

29051335.review:
A sliding puzzle game centered around an 80s slasher/horror VHS franchise. The game tends to get harder as you progress but there's a learning curve to help.

You get coins in between rounds to put towards new kill-cams and towards hints or solutions for 25 and 100 gold each, respectively.

Each VHS tape has over 10+ stages, with usually a few 'deleted scenes' which are just alternate takes on one of the already existant stages.

You can unlock many different models for your killer.

My only real complaints would be that the loading screen mini-games where you get coins are simple and repetitive, needing some variety and better mechanics.

The different kills you can buy for 500 to 2500 coins each are cool, but over-time they tend to become just annoying. It'd be nice to see them change a little bit/have more then one method of killing per style.

I'd love to see some references/odes to films and franchises like 'Killer Klowns from Outerspace', 'Leperchaun', 'Jack Frost', 'The Gingerdead Man', and 'Puppet Master' among others in the future.

At first it seems boring, but the more you play the more you'll love it.

[b] 10 camper kills / [b] 10

I recommend this game because it's fun, but I can't settle on that because it's not really helpful.

So basically, you're a killer who tries to kill every child at the level in gorey and gruesome ways. The catch is, you can only move in straight lines, so you can't directly walk over to the victims, you have to figure out how to get to them, making this the puzzle game that it is. The music is also pretty cool and fits well with the situation, and it's too bad I can't find the OST on YouTube or in the files because I'm a noob when it comes to computers.

28727035.review:
Poté, co jsem viděl trailer na tuhle hru, jsem ji musel koupit. Ta stylizace do osmdesátek mě prostě dostala. Jenže, jak je na tom vůbec tahle hra? Stojí opravdu za koupi?

[h1]Myšlenky zločince[/h1]
Hned zkraje musím sdělit, že i když to tak nemusí vypadat, tahle hra je především založená na logice. Pokud tedy neradi přemýšlíte, vyhněte se tomuto titulu. Ostatní nechť se posadí do kruhu kolem ohniště a já vám povyprávím příběh o vraždách, které se odehrály minulý rok v Slayaway kempu...

Ve hře Slayaway Camp se vtělíte do role vraha a váš úkol je prostý - pozabíjet všechny nevinné lidi. Je tu několik kampaní, které se postupně odemykají. V každé hrajete za někoho jiného a také místo dění oné vyvražďovačky se obměňuje. Vystřídáte tedy lokace jako je kemp, zábavní park, škola, vesmír atd.

Každá kampaň se skládá z několika levelů, kde musíte zabít určitý počet lidí a poté se zdárně dostat na určené místo. Vaši postavu ovládáte buď klávesnicí nebo klikáním myši. Herní plocha připomíná šachovnici, která je ale zaplněna různými věcmi a osobami. Váš zabiják se pohybuje podobně jako věž z šachů- když kliknete doprava, nejde jen o jedno pole, ale rovnou až na konec, dokud nenarazí na překážku. Díky tomuto aspektu musíte dopředu přemýšlet a ve vhodném pořadí cestovat po ploše a zabíjet lidi. Lidi můžete také vystrašit a tím je dostat na vámi preferovanou pozici, která někdy zahrnuje upálení zaživa nebo utopení nebohého človíčka.

[h1]Odpočinková hra[/h1]
Pokud nejste zelenáči mezi logickými hrami, vycítili jste jistě možnost hrát každý level na co nejmenší počet tahů a s tím související i nějakou odměnu. Bohužel nic takového tu není. Najdete v každé kampani jeden level, který musíte odehrát na předem daný počet tahů. U ostatních levelů ale nic takového není a hra to po vás nevyžaduje. Ono by to ani nedávalo smysl, když je tu velmi zajímavá nápověda. Za 24 mincí získáte tip na to, jak daný level splnit nebo na co si dávat pozor. Tyhle tipy jsou dost často užitečné, ale taktéž jsem si zpřístupnil některé, které mi vůbec nepomohly, jelikož jsem tuhle informaci již sám odhadl. Pokud ale dáte poté 100 mincí, hra vám ukáže zrychleně, jak jej splnit.

Hra je tedy dle mého zamýšlena spíše jako odpočinková záležitost, než zkouška vašeho intelektu. Levely jsou malé, díky čemuž tu není ani frustrace z toho, že máte hromadu možností, kam jít. Vaše postava totiž může i zemřít, když například šlápne na minu nebo se dostane do styku s členem SWAT týmu. Časem si těch věcí musíte hlídat opravdu hodně, ale celkově je hratelnost svižná a můžete se bez jakéhokoliv postihu vracet v tazích zpět.

[h1]Penízky, pojďte k tatínkovi[/h1]
Když jsem nahoře psal o mincích, mnozí z vás se jistě zhrozili, že tu jsou nějaké trapné mikrotransakce nebo tak. Herní měnu získáváte během miniher, které na vás čekají po dokončení každého levelu. Navíc se vám brzy zpřístupní i nekonečný mód, ve kterém jsou tyhle minihry a zde můžete získat hromadu peněz. Za ty si kupujete nejenom nápovědu, ale také další zabijáky a různé fatality. Fatalit bohužel není mnoho, tudíž se dost opakují a ztrácejí tak na efektivitě a zábavnosti. I přesto jsem je ale nepřeskakoval. Díky tomu, jak rychle a snadno jdou peníze vydělat, není problém odemknout vše ve hře.

Bohužel časem dochází k pomalému, ale jistému nástupu stereotypu. Hra se jej snaží neustále oddalovat a víceméně se jí to i daří. Pochopím ale, kdyby měl někdo potíže s dokončením všech levelů.

[h1]Osmdesátá léta jsou zpět[/h1]
Na závěr se pozastavím nad stylizací. Ta je jedním slovem parádní. Celé tohle dílo je oblečeno do osmdesátkového stylu, máte tu VHS kazety, béčkové popisy filmů, tajemného vypravěče a hromadu podivných způsobů, jak odejít z tohohle světa. V jednom z dílů hrajete třeba za napůl muže, napůl žraloka. V jiném zase za matku hlavního záporáka z předchozího dílu. Je tu tedy i humor. A krev. Hromada krve. Je to asi skutečně nejkrvavější logická hra, jakou jsem kdy hrál.

U stylizace může někomu vadit to, že je vše kostičkované. Ale já si na to velmi rychle zvykl a už mi to vůbec nevadí. No a pak tu je hudba. Ta je také skvělá, především písnička Only the Strong Survive, kterou si můžete pustit i v obchodě na Steamu. Z tohoto songu přímo čiší ona béčkovost a atmosféra osmdesátých let. Zvuky jsou taktéž dobré. Pochválit musím ale i takové animace, které působí kvalitním dojmem a když někoho vylekáte, je to i roztomilé. Ona postava se totiž začne třepat a vykulí oči :D

Hru jsem pořídil za 6,65 euro a jsem spokojený. Dostal jsem přesně to, co jsem chtěl a možná i něco navíc. Rozhodně jsem nečekal, jak moc to bude zábavné a stylové. Pokud si nejste jistí, doporučuji počkat na větší slevu.

[h1]Plusy[/h1]
+ návyková a jednoduchá hratelnost
+ atmosféra a stylizace osmdesátých let
+ kostičkovaná brutalita
+ úžasná hudba
+ různé lokace a postavy
+ kvalitní animace a celkově dobré technické zpracování
+ vtip

[h1]Mínusy[/h1]
- po čase nástup stereotypu
- zpočátku je hra až příliš jednoduchá
- fatality se po čase ohrají

[h1]Konečný verdikt[/h1]

28335185.review:
Games that send up the slasher genre seem to have boomed in the last few years, with Until Dawn on the PS4 and Dead by Daylight on PC. Slayaway Camp takes that idea and applies it to a genre that seems ill-fitting at first: puzzles. But it actually works surprisingly well.

You play as the various different killers in the Slayaway Camp horror series, starting with a clear homage to Jason, and moving on to different antagonists in films that have increasingly less and less to actually do with summer camp. You slide them around the levels and guide them into their hapless victims, then watch the carnage. Sounds simple enough, but Slayaway Camp doesn't waste time introducing different puzzle elements. Your killer can move in any four directions until they hit a solid wall or victim, and naturally there are many times you need to make careful use of the terrain to get where you need to be. Sometimes even getting to the end of the level is part of the puzzle.

Complicating this is that even if they're stoned idiots, your victims are still smart enough to turn and run away if you move next to them, or kill someone they're adjacent to. Depending on the level, you might need to avoid this happening or exploit it. Early on the game also introduces cops, who will arrest you if you end up in front of them. I don't want to give too much away, as there are two shelves worth of movies and each one adds some new mechanic to worry about. It's very solid gameplay-wise, and there are plenty of 'aha!' moments to be had. The game's also pretty nice about hints, and you can pay a reasonable amount of the game's currency to get a solution to a level you're really stuck on.

So it's good that the game has substance and isn't just the aesthetic - but the aesthetic is pretty good itself. The normal animation for killing a victim is just the killer sort of jumping on them, but if you like you can use coins to buy special ones that can show up instead. These are exactly the kinds of silly deaths you'd expect from a self-aware slasher movie, and they're all fun to watch. My only complaint with them, and with the game at all really, is that getting the coins to buy them can be difficult. You receive them by beating a simple timing mini-game after each level, or doing a gauntlet of them you can access from the level menu, which goes until you miss. Getting all of them sounds like it could be pretty grindy, even with the cheesy 80s ballad that plays during the latter.

Aside from that minor quibble, I quite enjoyed what I've played of Slayaway Camp. It's an oddly addicting game, and I'd definitely recommend it if you're into the slasher genre or just puzzles. If you like both, you may have found your mecca.

28101065.review:
A fun puzzle game with similar mechanics to [i] Hitman: Go, [/i] with a few notable differences in its gameplay. The most obvious of these differences is the way the player character is controlled. In [i] Hitman: Go, [/i] the player moves Agent 47 one tile at a time at their own discretion, whereas in [i] Slayaway Camp, [/i] the killer is controlled like a rook in chess, moving in a single direction until they reach an obstacle or teenager unfortunate to be in their presence. The solutions to the levels are also more concrete than those found in [i] Hitman, [/i] and typically don't offer room for variation in play style. 

The puzzles are well designed and often difficult, especially later in the game. The game introduces new mechanics in each of the subsequent level sets, such as SWAT officers that can only be killed by turning off lights in the level, telephones that can be used to lure away certain targets from their positions and electric fences that can be used to kill teenagers without getting your own hands dirty.   

The game also allows players to purchase (with in-game money) different killer characters and brutal ways of killing degenerate teenagers. The blocky, cartoony gore found in these unlockables is pretty amusing at first, but you'll probably find yourself skipping the short kill scenes after the first few times. The humor of the game is serviceable; if you're a fan of awful 90s slasher flicks then you'll definitely pick on some fun parodies of genre tropes.

Overall, a pretty good purchase if you're looking for a cheap time waster. Recommended.

27673659.review:
SUMMARY:  Buy it for the puzzles, keep playing it for the laughs.

TLDR:  I bought this game on a lark, expecting it to be more about splatter than puzzles.  Much to my surprise, however, there's a very good puzzle game in here under the simple cubist graphics and cheesy-just-to-be-cheesy farcing of the 1970s-80s ultra-campy slasher/splatter movies.  This is actually quite a legit sliding puzzle game and you get a couple hundred of them.  The puzzles get more and more complex as you go along, adding new elements that force you to devise new solutions and plan your moves well in advance.  But despite this, most puzzles are just the right size, not too long or too short.  It's just that instead of something like an elf picking up gems or whatever, it's a psycho killer painting the walls with blood and leaving body parts strewn about the floor.

The game's levels are called "movies", of which there are about 13.  Within each "movie",  there are 12-16 "scenes" which are the puzzles.  After completing a "movie", you unlock it's "deleted scenes", which are 5-7 additional and fairly challenging puzzles.  Each "movie" stars a different killer and introduces new puzzle features.  Usually the 1st 2 or 3 puzzles are very simple to make sure you understand the mechanics of the new features, but then you really have to start thinking.  Much of the solving process ultimately involves herding victims and arranging movable obstacles into specific places to let you not only kill all the victims but avoid traps and then reach the level's exit, all while avoiding police and not harming innocent animals.

Periodically, as you kill victims, short cut-scenes play showing a spoof of some classic slasher movie death scene. (you can click to skip these if you want).  A lot of the achievements revolve around unlocking new cut-scenes, which you do by buying them in the store.  You get a few coins for completing a puzzle, with a short, simple "click-at-the-right-time" thing to get a few more.  You can then spend these on a selection fo cut-scenes, which are called "gore packs".  You can also spend the coins on unlocking new random killers besides those who appear naturally in each "movie".  But none of this is essential to actually doing the puzzles, it's just a way to get into the whole splatter movie vibe plus collect achievements if you're into that.

Anyway, the puzzles are good and the presentation is funny.  Get it.

27426930.review:
What to say about this game that hasn't already been said by many others who are better with words than I am? That sentence alone points to a clear sign of why you should add this game to your library: it's popular as all f*ck. 

Right now, according to the store page, [i]Slayaway Camp[/i] is sitting pretty with an overall score of "Very Positive." OK, sure, the game did just release in October, but I hope to see the game community and devs continue to grow, as well as eventually see the day that this game is listed as "Overwhelmingly Positive." That's the kind of game it is.

Now, as Halloween is my favorite holiday, and I was in the midst of my month long rewatching of horror and slasher flicks, you can bet your ass that I bought this game, rather impulsively, within about five seconds of glancing over the store page. Let's be clear that I'm not the type to buy impulsively too much. 

THIS GAME IS A MASTERPIECE AND I'D EASILY BUY IT A SECOND OR THIRD TIME.

I also started up the game the day I bought it, another unheard-of action from a self-proclaimed games hoarder.[i] Slayaway Camp[/i] turned out to be everything I expected, and more. 

It's a simple premise, a slider type voxel game  where you control the killer and zip around the levels bringing the pain to unaware victims. The game isn't too difficult, if you're worried about that, but does ramp up the stakes with things like SWAT cops to avoid, electric fences, and even teleporters. With each new "movie", a collection of levels, I got more and more excited to see what new elements would be thrown in to puzzle my way out of.

The devs were also great and prompt about patching the game and fixing bugs, days and even weeks after the game's release. They also added some fun new content and really seemed to pay attention to what the players had to say. 

TL;DR: I need a Skullface plush, and will throw my money at the dev's faces if they make that happen. Also, this game has "deleted scenes" (extra levels) as well as NSFW scenes you can go back and play, so it's well worth your money for the content.

27369323.review:
In a Steam universe full of buggy, broken AAA titles, abandoned Early Access games, and developers selling DLC for games they haven't even finished, it's so refreshing to see a game that does what it sets out to do almost perfectly.  Slayaway Camp is a slider puzzle game presented as a love letter to one of the greatest of all movie genres - the 80s Slasher film.  You play as one of a series of psychotic klllers that pay homage to a host of horror icons; mostly from 80s greats like Friday the 13th and Halloween, but with a bit of bleed-over into the 70s and 90s for good measure.  You slide around the environment, avoiding obstacles and slaughtering helpless teenagers until everyone is dead and you can make your way to the exit.  

Each of the 10 scenarios is presented as an 80s-era movie on VHS tape, and consists of a dozen or so "scenes", with another 5 or 6 "deleted scenes" that are unlocked when you finish the main ones.  The puzzles range in difficulty, with some being actually quite hard, but hints are available if you need them.  Each movie gives you a new iconic killer to play, and more can be unlocked with coins you earn in-game.  You can also unlock a number of execution kills that randomly play through the course of the game.  It's not too difficult to gather enough coins for unlocks, but if you want to speed things along there's a separate mini-game that let's you grind out as much as you want.

I typically can't stand games with these sort of blocky, 8-bit "retro" graphics, but there's an exception to every rule and this one's it.  One of Slayaway Camp's greatest features is its sense of humor and tongue-in-cheek approach to the subject matter, and watching all these little teens being slaughtered in shockingly brutal ways ends up being quite hilarious when you see it in all its blocky, pixelated glory.   We get enough [i]realistic[/i] brutality in other games - this game is about [i]charming, fun[/i] brutality, and it succeeds at that brilliantly.  In fact, pretty much everything that Slayaway Camp tries to do, it does exceedingly well.  I haven't had this much genuine fun with a game in quite a while, and I wholeheartedly recommend it.

11/24/17 - Just updatin'. Game's still awesome.

[h1] Полноценный обзор со скриншотами вы можете прочитать здесь: [url=https://doggamingsite.wordpress.com/2016/11/24/slayaway-camp/] Обзоры от Mad4Cookie[/url][/h1]

Slayaway Camp - это пазл-игра в стиле слешеров 70-90хх годов. Разработчиками данного проекта выступила команда, явно любящих хоррор фильмы, Blue Wizard Digital Ltd.

Ребята из студии явно пересмотрели все фильмы, которые так любит поколение 80-х годов. Пресловутые Джейсон Вурхиз, Майкл Майерс, Фреди Крюгер, Кожаное лицо, ксеноморфы и прочие "любимчики" детей того поколения, нашли своеобразное перерождение в этой игре. Да, настоящих имен в игре вы не найдете, но как же много отсылок к нашим любимым слешерам. Скажу вам честно, я заметил проект, когда и просматривал канал знаменитого ютубера: Markiplier. Мне проект сразу запал в душу, и я постарался найти и пообщаться с разработчиком, чтобы этот обзор мог существовать. За 5 часов игры я прошел не так много, просто пытался множество уровней пройти разными путями (к сожалению в отдельно взятых локациях есть всего один вариант прохождения). Суть игры - играем за маньяка и стараемся развязать пазл, который позволить убить всех людей на локации и уйти безнаказанно. Как по мне идеальный сценарий и отличная интерпретация.

Начинается наш нелегкий путь маньяка с "Кристального озера"(не совсем) в шкуре "SkullFace"(привет Джейсону Вурхизу). Главная задача убить всех детишек, которые побеспокоили наше мирное существование. С первого же убийства вы можете просто влюбится в игру за ее жестокость и кровожадность. Я, к большому счастью, отношусь к тем людям, которые пересмотрели все части "Пятница 13", "Кошмар на улице вязов", "Хэллоуин" и т.д., помногу раз. Поэтому подобный проект как Slayaway Camp - просто находка, ведь в нем так удачно соединились жанры: кровожадный слешер и головоломающий пазл. По сути ваш персонаж может двигаться только по вертикали и горизонтали (чем то похоже на шахматную фигуру под названием: "Ладья"), если по пути ему встретится препятствие любого вида, убийца остановится перед ней. Таким образом вам необходимо продумать на много шагов вперед, чтобы не попасть в безвыходную ситуацию из которой только один выход - смерть.

Графическая составляющая игры держит планку стандартного пазла, но с элементами разчлененки. Выглядит кроваво, круто, в духе старых добрых 80-х. На каждой локации уникальные декорации, живые (до поры, до времени) люди, которые боятся маньяка, хотя иногда в упор его не замечают сбоку от себя, пазлы продуманны настолько хорошо, что можно зависнуть в игре надолго пытаясь найти альтернативные источники прохождения уровня. Звуковое сопровождение просто шикарно подчеркивает хоррор составляющую игры. Звуки когда маньяк настигают жертву, сопровождаются таким знакомым и "родным" звуком из фильмов ужасов 80-90хх годов. Проходить сложнейшие пазлы под такую музыку и с такой тематикой игры - просто непередаваемо.

Под конец обзора хотелось бы перечислить плюсы и минусы проекта.

Плюсы:
+ Присутствие духа слешеров 80-90-хх годов
+ Порой довольно трудные пазлы
+ Большое разнообразие играбельных маньяков
+ Разнообразие в экзекуции жертвы
+ Хорошая графика
+ Изумительное музыкальное сопровождение

Минусы:
- Нет функции рогалика

Slayaway Camp - изумительный хоррор-пазл от молодой и перспективной группы разработчиков. Один незначительный минус не испортил мое общее впечатление от игры. Заношу Slayaway Camp в разряд игр обязательных к прохождению за 2016 год. Оценочка 10 из 10.

[b][i] *За этот обзор я благодарен разработчику, который предоставил ключ от данной игры. Однако это никак не повлияло на мой личный взгляд на проект. [/i][/b]

26999400.review:
You'll find plenty of people talking about Slayaway Camp's humorous setting, but let's talk gameplay. Slayaway Camp, at it's core, is the tried and true ice-sliding puzzle, where pressing a movement key pushes you as far as you can go in that direction. Your objective is to murder all the people (except the cops) by moving into them, then getting to a designated exit point.

Moving into a person kills them, but leaves you stationary, potentially leaving you in a row or column of the grid you couldn't otherwise access. So, the position of people becomes important. People will also run away from you if you occupy a square adjacent to them, or kill someone who is adjcent to them, and they will run in the opposite direction as far as they can go. So, we get, in addition to the ice sliding puzzle, a block pushing game, but one where the blocks can't directly be pushed! Often the trickiness in the puzzles arises from deftly manipulating the scared people into being in the exact position you want them to be. Although, some of the puzzles have a limited number of moves, so the challenge is in being efficient.

Slayaway Camp's learning curve is quite gentle. Over its hundreds of puzzles, it drips down several new mechanics, and always presents an easy puzzle or two that forces you to explore the implications of the new mechanic. The overall difficulty increases gradually, and it may take 60-90 minutes before a more seasoned puzzle game player begins to feel the challenge. But, rest assured, the puzzles do become challenging, and remain that way for the majority of this surprisingly lengthy game.

What's more, they are definitely the good kind of challenging. I rarely found myself wandering aimlessly to see what I could accomplish. My method for solving a new puzzle was to dive in and see what I could accomplish. Then the difficulties of the level would present itself (How can I get to the exit? How do I get that last teenager in the middle of the room? etc). More often than not, by working backwards from these difficulties, I could figure out a blueprint for what I needed to get done, and in what order. It was a fun, intellectual experience, rather than a frustrating experience of headbutting a brick wall until it cracks (although, some of the move-limited puzzles were more like this).

I highly recommend Slayaway Camp. It's extraordinary value, and the developers have clearly crafted it with both love and skill. Speaking of the developers, they are highly responsive both to bug reports and suggestions for future expansions. Do yourself a favour and pick it up.

26955388.review:
[h1]Slashy Slashy[/h1]

Do you love slasher movies?  Slayaway Camp loves slasher movies.  This throwback to the slasher movies of the 80's absolutely does justice to the genre while simultaneously satirizing it to great appeal.  Instead of being a straight-up "survive the madman" horror game, this game spins that around to where you are a cute voxel murderer cheerfully plowing through scores of victims in the most over-the-top ways possible.  The puzzle mechanics, aesthetics, and extra content all blend together to create a unique slasher experience

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Mechanics-wise, this is first an foremost a puzzle game.  You are a killer sliding around a puzzle map, navigating obstacles, avoiding cops, killing generic victims and escaping through your satanic portal (yes, you heard me correctly) to move on to the next puzzle.  Normally this would get old fast, but thankfully the game keeps things fresh by introducing different mechanics throughout the game.  This makes the game more interesting, not to mention vexingly harder, as you progress, especially when different mechanics start being combined to create some of the most difficult puzzles I have every seen.

However, the game doesn't explain very well how some of the mechanics work or affect other mechanics, like how lights affect the cops or telephones affect cats.  You will almost always die several times learning how the mechanics work before completing the puzzle.  For those that prefer this type of experiential learning, it won't matter.  But for those of us who prefer not being virtually set up for failure, it's annoying.

I would be remiss if I didn't mention the bonus game at the end of each puzzle.  You get to try and earn an extra kill by timing a button press to land your sliding marker in the "Kill Zone."  It's a neat little distraction, and it earns you coins to spend in the shop.  More on that later.

[b]Aesthetics[/b]

This game looks and sounds like bits were ripped out of every 80's slasher movie known to man and Frankensteined together.  While primarily based on Friday the 13th, you'll find nods to Jaws, The Ring, H.P. Lovecraft's work, and even Mars Attacks!  All of it brought to life effortlessly through the voxel-style art direction.  Even the menus are made up to look like those VHS video stores where one used to rent slasher movies from.

The soundtrack's pretty awesome, too.  Sure its got those stereotypical (and very well done) horror underscores, but it even remembers to include the cheesy 80's rock songs that accompany every slasher movie ending credits.

And the kills.  Oh my word, the kills.  Every kill imaginable (and previously unimaginable) is shown in glorious over-the-top fashion.  I have never laughed so hard at saxophone slayings or death-by-deep-fried-sugar.

[b]Extra Content[/b]

There are two different types of unlockable extras - killers and kills.  Killers cost 1000 coins each (from winning those extra-kill mini games) while kills cost between 1000 and 2000 coins.  There is a large variety of kills you can pick from, but killers are earned by opening a "mystery box" and randomly winning a killer.  This irks me because I really wanted one of the killers ([spoiler]The JimSaw Killer[/spoiler]) but as of yet haven't attained him.

My other minor gripe is that once you purchase a kill, you can't preview it in the store.  You have to either wait until it randomly appears in the game, or move over to the trophy shelf.  It just seems unnecessary to have the extra steps.  I dunno, maybe I'm just crazy.

There are other extras included, but I think I'll leave them for you to learn about on your own.

[b]In Conclusion[/b]

Definitely worth getting for any fan of puzzle games or 80's slasher flicks.  It's great in both regards and stands out heads above other puzzle games because of that seamless blend. 

What else is there to say but "Love is Like a Machete to the Heart"

[b]Final Verdict: 9/10 [/b]



[i]Note: This review is done for the Steam Awards 2016's "I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award" award. Please nominate this game for that award so we can all be vindicated if it wins.  Thank you! [/i]

26934592.review:
For the tiny price and even tinier install size, you would expect (and be satisfied with) a fun little 2-3 hour distraction here, but as I approach hour 13 I am still loving this game and nowhere near finishing.

This is a deceptively simple puzzle game that uses only the four direction keys (or d pad), but the difficulty curve is constructed ideally. New mechanics are introduced regularly, you spend 2 or 3 puzzles getting your head around them, another 4 or 5 feeling pretty smug about mastering them, and then just as you might be on the verge of starting to feel it's all gotten a little dull there's a new mechanic and another devilish reinvention of an old one to test you again.

Those mechanics aren't just dry challenge-enhancers either, they're fun, well-animated riffs on all sorts of horror movie tropes that always raise a smile. In fact the whole thing is wrapped up in a nice retro-styled 'video-nasty' presentation that proves the retro aesthetic isn't quite completely wrung-out just yet, as long as it's done well and in service of a good game.

Slayaway Camp is funny without trying too hard, endearing without being cutesy and irreverent without being annoying. It's pitched PERFECTLY and everyone should play it.
